content.question: The second derivative of the function <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is given by <math alttext="g double prime of x, equals, 0.1 times x to the fifth power, minus 0.29 times x to the fourth power, minus, 0.694 times x cubed, plus 1.9136 times x squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>″</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>0.1</mn><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>0.29</mn><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>0.694</mn><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>1.9136</mn><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></math>. At which values of <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> in the interval <math alttext="negative 3 is less than x, is less than 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> does the graph of <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> have a point of inflection where the concavity of the graph changes from concave up to concave down?

choices.label: <math alttext="x equals, negative 2.6" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2.6</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="x equals, 3.2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3.2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> only

topic.text: 5.6: Determining Concavity of Functions over Their Domains

skill.text: Skill 2.E: Describe the relationships among different representations of functions and their derivatives.
